content: How can I help you today?
Hi, my partner thinks I should talk to someone because I haven't been sleeping well. I’m not too sure how this can help, but I’m willing to give it a shot.

Thank you for sharing that and for being open to this conversation. It sounds like sleep has been a challenge for you lately, and your partner cares enough to encourage you to take a step toward finding support. What has sleep been like for you recently?

Honestly, it’s been pretty rough. My mind races at night, and I can't seem to stop thinking about work and everything that’s going on. I end up scrolling through my phone just to distract myself, but I know it's not helping. I just feel stuck.

It sounds like your mind is feeling overloaded, and those racing thoughts make it hard to relax and drift off. Scrolling on your phone seems like a way to escape, but it hasn’t brought the relief you’re hoping for. That feeling of being stuck must be frustrating. What do you think is contributing most to your mind racing?

I think it’s the stress from work. I’m worried about getting fired, especially with how the company’s been struggling. If that happens, I don’t know how I’ll take care of my family. It’s always on my mind, and I can’t seem to shut it off.

The stress from work and the fear of losing your job sound really overwhelming, especially with the weight of thinking about your family’s wellbeing. It’s understandable that these worries would be hard to let go of, even when you’re trying to rest. How do you usually handle stress when it builds up like this?

Honestly, I don't think I've been handling it that well. I just push through the days and keep everything bottled up. I don’t really talk about it because I feel like I should be able to figure it out on my own, but it’s getting harder to keep everything together.

It sounds like you’ve been carrying a lot on your own, and pushing through may have felt like the only option. Keeping everything bottled up might help you avoid burdening others, but it also seems like it’s taking a toll. Sharing this here is definitely a courageous step. What do you think might make it easier for you to start managing this stress in a way that feels right for you?

I'm not really sure, to be honest. I feel like the stress isn't going away anytime soon, and I don't even know where to begin. Maybe if I could just stop overthinking for a while, but that feels impossible right now.

It sounds like the stress and overthinking have been so persistent that it’s hard for you to see a way forward right now. Feeling like it’s impossible can make it even harder to take that first step. It’s a big deal that you’re talking about it and looking for help, though. Is there anything you’ve done in the past—whether small or big—that has helped calm your mind, even briefly?

I can’t really think of much that works for me right now. Sometimes I used to go for a walk or play music, but lately, even those things don’t seem to help. It feels like my mind jumps right back to all the worries no matter what I try.

That sounds frustrating—to feel like even the things that once helped, like walking or playing music, aren’t giving you the relief you need right now. It seems like you’re really searching for a way to quiet your worries but feeling stuck when your mind keeps pulling you back to them. What would it be like for you if you could find a way to ease even just a little bit of that mental pressure?

Honestly, it would feel like such a relief. I don’t expect everything to suddenly get better, but even finding a way to have moments of peace would be a huge help. I just don’t know how to get there on my own.

Having even moments of peace sounds like something that could make a meaningful difference for you. It’s understandable to feel unsure about how to create those moments, especially when it feels like you’re carrying everything on your own. Since you’re open to exploring this, is there anything else you’d like to share about what’s been making this chapter in your life feel so heavy?

It’s just the constant feeling of pressure—being a good provider for my family, dealing with work stress, and trying to keep it together for everyone. I also worry that all of this is affecting my relationship with my kids because I’m so distracted and tired all the time. It’s like I’m physically there but not really present, and that makes me feel even worse.

It sounds like a heavy load you’ve been carrying—between the pressures of providing, work stresses, and being there for your family. Feeling distracted and disconnected from your kids seems like it really pains you because it matters so much to you to be present for them. Balancing all of this while running on little rest must feel exhausting. What would being more present look like to you, if things felt lighter?

It would probably mean being able to focus on my time with my kids, really listening to them and enjoying those little moments without my mind drifting back to work or stress. I’d love to feel like I’m showing up for them fully and being someone they can depend on and look up to. Right now, it feels like I’m falling short on that.

You clearly care deeply about being there for your kids and being the kind of parent they can depend on and admire. It matters to you to savor those little moments with them, and feeling like you’re falling short must weigh heavily on you. Even though things feel tough, you’re here talking about it, which shows how much you’re trying to move in the direction you want. What do you think needs to happen for you to start moving closer to feeling more present in those moments?

It would probably mean finding a way to let go of some of the stress and not letting it take over my thoughts all the time. That sounds easier said than done, though. I know I need to find a way to deal with everything better, but I don’t even know where to start.

Letting go of some of the stress feels like it could help you reconnect with the things that matter most to you, but the thought of figuring out how to do that might seem overwhelming right now. The fact that you’re recognizing both the need for change and the challenges involved is an important step forward. Is there anything else you want to talk about before discussing ways to get started?
